839bc7ed2771b6f3310f45a914979e59 (19:28): is a PROXY a protocol itself
839bc7ed2771b6f3310f45a914979e59 (19:28): or it uses another protocol?
a6dfa26a18ef640700a1ccc01a3efe23 (19:28): I think a protocol
a6dfa26a18ef640700a1ccc01a3efe23 (19:29): http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proxy_server
d53a9ce77f40534cd0a1ee00cb6b8f3f (19:34): depends, you are referring to two types of thing
d53a9ce77f40534cd0a1ee00cb6b8f3f (19:34): TCP is a low level transmission protocol
d53a9ce77f40534cd0a1ee00cb6b8f3f (19:34): a proxy server operates an application level protocol like SOCKS over TCP

a7424a9664cceb903b4234beceaa8c6c (20:30): what's the meaning of the "@" in string path = @"c:\MyDir";?
92d98c96f88d71ffe91cc99c96d3739c (20:31): it ignores all special characters in the string
a7424a9664cceb903b4234beceaa8c6c (20:31): ah , thanks jamx
d827dc4b3ca3c1a1c198e14ebdb8da71 (20:39): that doesn't quite explain it 100%
d827dc4b3ca3c1a1c198e14ebdb8da71 (20:39): it doesn't ignore them, it just doesn't have escape code processing
a6dfa26a18ef640700a1ccc01a3efe23 (20:39): hey anyone know what the word ciao means >.<

d827dc4b3ca3c1a1c198e14ebdb8da71 (20:40): there is nevertheless a way to embed a " character into the string without terminating it: just use two of them in a row to get a single character insidet he string
d827dc4b3ca3c1a1c198e14ebdb8da71 (20:40): the other thing that @ strings can do is embed newlines directly, as in: string two_lines = @"first_line
d827dc4b3ca3c1a1c198e14ebdb8da71 (20:40): second_line";
d827dc4b3ca3c1a1c198e14ebdb8da71 (20:40): it's useful for things like help/usage messages in console applications, and very large messageboxes, and stuff
a7424a9664cceb903b4234beceaa8c6c (20:41): logiclrd, string bla = "bla ""bla"" bla"; is "bla "bla" bla"?
d827dc4b3ca3c1a1c198e14ebdb8da71 (20:42): tuxipuxi: er, well, if I'm understanding you correctly, yes :-)
d827dc4b3ca3c1a1c198e14ebdb8da71 (20:42): er wait, no, you need a @ at the start of the literal :-)
d827dc4b3ca3c1a1c198e14ebdb8da71 (20:42): string bla = @"bla ""bla"" bla";
d827dc4b3ca3c1a1c198e14ebdb8da71 (20:42): without the '@', strings are essentially the same as C/C++/Java
d827dc4b3ca3c1a1c198e14ebdb8da71 (20:42): these two are equivalent: string bla = @"bla ""bla"" bl"; and string bla = "bla \"bla\" bla";
d827dc4b3ca3c1a1c198e14ebdb8da71 (20:42): does that explain it? :-)
a7424a9664cceb903b4234beceaa8c6c (20:43): logiclrd, ah so the double " is to work around the limitation that @ brings into the game?
d827dc4b3ca3c1a1c198e14ebdb8da71 (20:43): yep
a7424a9664cceb903b4234beceaa8c6c (20:43): yeah, explains it, thanks :)
d827dc4b3ca3c1a1c198e14ebdb8da71 (20:43): I don't see it as a limitation, though, because it actually makes it *easier* for the majority of strings :-)
d827dc4b3ca3c1a1c198e14ebdb8da71 (20:43): especially windows-style pahts
d53a9ce77f40534cd0a1ee00cb6b8f3f (20:43): Sin-Ra - ciao is goodbye in spanish! pronouned "chow"
d827dc4b3ca3c1a1c198e14ebdb8da71 (20:43): @"C:\Path\To\File.txt"
d827dc4b3ca3c1a1c198e14ebdb8da71 (20:44): as opposed to "C:\\Path\\To\\File.txt"
d827dc4b3ca3c1a1c198e14ebdb8da71 (20:44): which is more readable? :-)
a7424a9664cceb903b4234beceaa8c6c (20:45): yeah indeed :)
d53a9ce77f40534cd0a1ee00cb6b8f3f (20:46): the most useful context i find is in Regex where you really don't want to make it more complicated by doubling \s: "\\s[hH][eE][lL][lL][oO]\\s\\d{4}"
d53a9ce77f40534cd0a1ee00cb6b8f3f (20:46): much nicer with an @

4e4a1d6be8381146ecaf0b89f6f89ae9 (20:54): I wanted to write an app that would accept two images and horizontally stitch them together.
2c3d5444b82d166418989181b012f2d8 (20:54): shaynes: do you want to learn or do panorama pics?
4e4a1d6be8381146ecaf0b89f6f89ae9 (20:54): I am pretty new to C# and came up with a clean method that seems to work just fine, except, it's slow.
2c3d5444b82d166418989181b012f2d8 (20:54): I have a *great* app for panorama stitch
2c3d5444b82d166418989181b012f2d8 (20:54): it just takes a set of images and does it's magic
2c3d5444b82d166418989181b012f2d8 (20:54): no questions asked
4e4a1d6be8381146ecaf0b89f6f89ae9 (20:55): ikea: It doesn't need any smart logic as the two images are pixel perfect.
4e4a1d6be8381146ecaf0b89f6f89ae9 (20:55): Here's what I wrote, http://pastebin.ca/170386, any suggestions on switching up my methods to make things faster?
4e4a1d6be8381146ecaf0b89f6f89ae9 (20:56): ikea: Would you offer up the source to the project? or is this some closed app you know of?
2c3d5444b82d166418989181b012f2d8 (20:56): shaynes: afaik it's closed source and not .net
4e4a1d6be8381146ecaf0b89f6f89ae9 (20:57): ikea: is it really mispelled like that?
4e4a1d6be8381146ecaf0b89f6f89ae9 (20:57): stich?
4e4a1d6be8381146ecaf0b89f6f89ae9 (20:57): ikea: ok, just checking.
4e4a1d6be8381146ecaf0b89f6f89ae9 (20:57): ikea: never know these days, crap like pluggd or flickr, etc...
4e4a1d6be8381146ecaf0b89f6f89ae9 (20:58): ikea: Judging by the default icon it has, I think it was written in C++ using MFC
4e4a1d6be8381146ecaf0b89f6f89ae9 (21:01): ikea: it didn't work.
4e4a1d6be8381146ecaf0b89f6f89ae9 (21:01): I downloaded it.
4e4a1d6be8381146ecaf0b89f6f89ae9 (21:02): Anyone have any comments on the pastebin? http://pastebin.ca/170386
2c3d5444b82d166418989181b012f2d8 (21:06): shaynes: it worked perfect with 16 pics I took with my cellphone
2c3d5444b82d166418989181b012f2d8 (21:06): did a perfect panorama of them
2c3d5444b82d166418989181b012f2d8 (21:06): and they were low quality and didn't really line up everywhere
d53a9ce77f40534cd0a1ee00cb6b8f3f (21:07): shaynes - why don't you use the Graphics namespace
d53a9ce77f40534cd0a1ee00cb6b8f3f (21:07): 2 secs, I'll look up the exact function you want
d53a9ce77f40534cd0a1ee00cb6b8f3f (21:08): create a new System.Drawing.Graphics object then use the DrawImage function
d53a9ce77f40534cd0a1ee00cb6b8f3f (21:09): rather than copying it pixel by pixel
d53a9ce77f40534cd0a1ee00cb6b8f3f (21:09): will be much faster
d53a9ce77f40534cd0a1ee00cb6b8f3f (21:09): http://msdn2.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.drawing.graphics.drawimage.aspx
